DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to determine whether the noninvasive ventilation is more effective in the treatment of severe comunity acquired pneumonia in comparison with the conventional mechanical ventilation with orotracheal intubation.
DOC.brief_title: Efects of Noninvasive Mechanical Ventilation and Conventional Mechanical Ventilation in Patients With Severe Comunity Pneumonia
DOC.criteria: The criteria for the diagnosis of SCAP included: Blood systolic pressure lower than 90 mmHg or blood diastolic pressure lower than 60 mmHg RR higher than 30 breaths per minute PaO2/FiO2 lower than 250 while breathing through a Venturi mask with a 50% inspired oxygen fraction (FiO2) Bilateral or multiple lobar infiltrations evidenced by thorax Xray, and Use of vasopressor drugs Exclusion criteria included: COPD Asthma Acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema Severe haemodynamic instability (arterial systolic pressure lower than 70 mmHg) or requirements of vasoactive drugs Glasgow score equal to or lower than 9 or requiring OTI for airway protection or for recent pulmonary resucitation Antecedents of respiratory failure resulting from neuromuscular pathology Failure of two or more organs Facial deformities; and Recent facial, aesophagic and gastric surgeries
